ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
DIGGINGS OF ROADS
(Expenditure)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chiam See Tong -

    To ask the Acting Minister for National Development (a) why there were so many repetitive diggings of roads all over Singapore by the Public Works Department and other statutory boards from 1989 to 1993; and (b) how much was spent on those road diggings by the PWD in each of those years.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin (Toa Payoh GRC): Question No. 1, Sir.

     The Acting Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, road openings are carried out by the various services departments, such as PUB, Telecom and the Sewerage Department to lay their services.

Column: 972



    The PWD regulates and coordinates the road opening activities of these services departments. The Road Opening Coordination Committee (ROCC), chaired by PWD, meets monthly to coordinate all road openings. This Committee comprises members from various authorities, such as the Traffic Police, PUB, Telecom, Environment and MRTC.

    Repeated road diggings are sometimes unavoidable. Firstly, many services cannot be laid close to one another. For example, a sewer line cannot be laid next to a water main. Similarly, an electrical cable cannot be laid next to a gas line. Secondly, the total closure of a road or the closure of many traffic lanes along a road is not permitted, to minimise inconvenience to road users. Hence, the services departments are not allowed to carry out more than one trench opening along a road at any one time to minimise road congestion. The ROCC coordinates their work programmes so that only one road opening takes place at any one time. This may have given the public the misconception of repeated road openings along the same road.

    The PWD does not have the cost incurred by the various services departments on road openings.

ARTICLE BY MR CHERIAN GEORGE IN STRAITS TIMES
(Statement by the Leader of the House)


     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Mr Speaker, Sir, on Friday, 11th March 1994, I informed this House that the article entitled "Hold the guillotine when issues are of public concern" by Mr Cherian George, published in the column "From the Gallery" in the Straits Times on 10th March 1994, was a breach of Parliamentary privilege and a contempt of Parliament. I told Members that I hoped Mr George, after reading my clarification of the procedures which apply to the Committee of Supply and to Members who wish to raise issues for debate, would withdraw unconditionally his criticisms of the proceedings, the Speaker and Deputy Speaker, and publish this retraction in the same "From the Gallery" column in

Column: 973

the Straits Times. I also said that after I had read Mr George's response to my statement, I would decide whether it was necessary to make a formal complaint to the Committee of Privileges.

    Mr George responded to my statement in the "From the Gallery" column in the Straits Times of 12th March, entitled "No malice - and no offence meant". I quote:

    `I am glad I am given the opportunity to clarify my comments.

    They were most definitely not written in malice.

    I wrote the column out of a sincere desire to give constructive feedback to an institution which I hold in high regard.

    I did not presume in my column to say, nor did it ever cross my mind, that the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker had been unfair and improper in the way they applied the guillotine that day.

    Therefore I regret very much that my column, in Mr Wong's words, carried the innuendo that "the Speaker and Deputy Speaker had stifled debate and were not using the guillotine procedure in a fair and proper manner".

    I apologise unreservedly for having created this impression in any reader.

    At no time did I or the editors with whom I discussed my column prior to writing it, ever feel that debate had been "stifled" or the guillotine abused.

    I agree with Mr Wong entirely that coming to such a conclusion would certainly be "an unjust reflection on the conduct of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker in the discharge of their duties".

    I withdraw my offending words unconditionally.

    Indeed, as someone who has attended most Parliament sittings over the past 3 1/2 years, I am only too happy to put on record my respect for the Speaker and his deputies.

    In the eyes of this citizen, they have, at all times, discharged their duties with fairness and dignity.'

    Sir, Mr George has thus promptly and unconditionally withdrawn his criticisms and apologised for the innuendo in his article of 10th March. In view of this prompt response from Mr George, I will not refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges but will treat it as closed.

     Mr Speaker: In view of the unreserved apology and unconditional retraction by Mr Cherian George and the remarks of the Leader of the House, I will now treat the matter as closed.

ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR
1ST APRIL, 1994 TO 31ST MARCH, 1995

    Head W (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [11th March, 1994],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head W of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr Ow Chin Hock].

    Question again proposed.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Eunos GRC): Sir, I noted that some $350 million will be set aside for a research and development fund to be administered by the National Science and Technology Board for the promotion and development of R&D projects in Singapore. This is a big sum of money and I know it is always difficult to quantify the benefits of money spent on R&D projects. But, nevertheless, I would still like the Minister to explain to the House how the money spent on R&D projects in the past has benefited Singaporeans in the Singapore economy. What will the $350 million to be set aside for the next fiscal year be used for and how will this sum of money further benefit Singaporeans?

     Dr Ow Chin Hock (Leng Kee): Sir, the Economic Development Board (EDB) and Trade Development Board (TDB) have done a good job in promoting our economic growth in the past. They have now taken on a new mission in helping Singapore enterprises venturing abroad. Existing schemes are modified, eg, EDB's Local Enterprise Finance Scheme was expanded to include financing approved overseas projects, and TDB's Market Development Scheme was extended to include investment development activities.

    However, there are also rising expectations among local SMEs on what EDB and TDB can do and should do in helping them going regional. Let me summarise some suggestions and feedback from local SMEs and the business community on the role of EDB and TDB:

Column: 975



    1 EDB and TDB should collect and provide more detailed investment and business information on targeted countries. The information should include investment environment, business regulations, tax policy, exchange rate policy, and labour quality. The TDB's resource library needs to be beefed up.

    2 Internally, EDB and TDB should be more proactive in disseminating information on their incentive and assistance schemes. Apart from the Enterprise Promotion Centre, such information can be channelled to various Chambers of Commerce and relevant trade associations. The information should make the criteria for eligibility for various schemes as transparent as possible.

    3 Externally, overseas offices of EDB and TDB should be adequately staffed so that they can be more effective in assisting Singaporeans overseas, and in collecting information on investment and business conditions. In this context, I wish to know whether the turnover rate of the two statutory boards in the last two years was more serious than in the past, especially among the more senior staff.

    4 Finally, EDB and TDB should organise more dialogue sessions with SMEs and Chambers of Commerce on a regular basis to exchange views and information. There was a related suggestion that EDB and TDB can help to set up an association for Singapore overseas entrepreneurs and businessmen to share their experiences, and to provide a forum for the private sector to interact with statutory boards, GLCs and relevant Ministries and departments.

    May I have the Minister's comments on these suggestions?

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson GRC): Sir, regionalisation is a key strategy to continue sustaining Singapore's economic expansion. I can envisage that if this strategy turns out to be very successful, the demand on our manpower will be very high. This demand will be particularly heavy for people in the managerial, supervisory and skilled grades.

    I would like to express my concern that, in addition to the fear that there could be a

Column: 976

hollowing out of our industries caused by the businesses shifting to the less developed countries in this region, there may also be a risk of hollowing out of our trained and skilled manpower as well. In simple language, if everybody is going overseas to work, who is left to take care of things back in Singapore?

    Sir, please allow me to explain my concern. As I can envisage it, at present, the regionalisation drive will only involve the CEOs and top managers who travel out to the region to source for and land business deals and contracts. I understand that even at this initial stage, the key people in the Government sector and in the private sector are already very stretched due to the numerous overseas trips. But after securing the contracts, the next level will involve middle management and supervisory personnel who will also be very much needed in implementing the projects. Hence, I have a fear that the middle management and skilled personnel will be overly stretched in time for them to attend to the domestic as well as foreign operations of their companies.

    The constraint on our ability to invest overseas will not be limited by our capital since Singapore has quite ample capital in reserves both by companies and the public sector. We will be constrained more by the lack of manpower. Our contributions to all these overseas projects will not only be the transfer of technology but also the transfer of software, such as in management techniques and management control.

    Therefore, I would like to urge the Minister to inform the House as to how his Ministry intends to cater for the necessary manpower planning and training of our local workforce to meet the expanding needs arising from more and more businesses venturing overseas in future. I can propose three measures that can be taken into account to attend to the problem of increasing demand for manpower for overseas projects.

    First is for his Ministry to start to plan in the middle and longer term on how more manpower for overseas projects can be

Column: 977

trained in our tertiary institutions. This means that the Ministry has to look into its manpower planning and training now so that we can cater for the future. For example, if there is a need for more engineers and technicians, then the required intakes for polytechnic and university students for these courses will have to start now.

    The second solution is for employers to consider how they can recruit suitable managerial and supervisory personnel from the countries where their projects are based. It is natural that the local personnel from these countries where the overseas projects are located be used and recruited, as these people will be best suited to supervise the lower level of workers and operators. However, these managers may have to be trained in Singapore to be instilled with the right knowledge and technology before they can be effective.

    The third solution I can suggest is that employers should not only draw from the domestic pool in Singapore and the countries where the projects are located but should also look towards other countries in the region where these people can be recruited. And these foreign staff can be specially earmarked for the overseas projects. For example, we know that unemployment in Australia is now quite high and, therefore, there could be professionals from Australia who are prepared to work for Singapore companies in these overseas projects. These people should be given the initial training in Singapore. Then they can be sent to supervise projects in other countries like India, Indochina and China.

    But to facilitate these two processes of employing personnel from other foreign countries or from the foreign countries where the projects are based, I would like the Minister to be more flexible in allowing local companies to recruit foreign professionals and to enable them to work in Singapore for short stints of 6-12 months, and these personnel should not be subject to the normal local rules of immigration and employment conditions,

Column: 978

such as the percentage of local and foreign workers that can be allowed to work in Singapore companies.

    I urge the Minister to consider these proposals.
1.45 pm

     Mr Chew Heng Ching: Sir, the Government has set aside a $1 billion Cluster Development Fund for the EDB to make investments of strategic value to Singapore together with the private sector. Sir, this is a large sum of money. I think Members of the House deserve some clarification from the Minister on the objectives and uses of this Fund. For how long would this money be spent and for what projects? What types of industries are considered strategic to us today? How will investments in such industries be of benefit to Singapore in general, to Singaporean companies and to the man-in-the-street?

    Sir, making money available for this Cluster Development Fund is one thing. Having the management expertise and experience to be able to invest and manage the fund is another. I would therefore like to ask the Minister whether EDB has the resources and the management expertise to evaluate investment proposals for the use of the Cluster Development Fund. What safeguards do the Government have against misuse of the Fund? Would the Minister like to clarify these various points?

    Sir, there has also been a suggestion by Dr Wong Kwei Cheong during the Budget debate last week that the fund be used for investments overseas as part of our regionalisation drive. Sir, I caution against this. I think we should invest the fund in Singapore to directly benefit the Singapore economy. Would the Minister comment on this suggestion?

     Dr Ow Chin Hock (Leng Kee)( In Mandarin): Sir, in order to improve the competitiveness of our economy and to restructure our economy, we have to keep on upgrading the skills of our workers and to provide retraining for workers who have been redeployed. Under this major premise, I support the increase in the

Column: 979

salary ceiling for SDF levy collection from $750 to $1,000 per month. The reason is very simple: with less and less workers earning a salary of $750 and below, the collection from the SDF levy is decreasing. On the other hand, training and upgrading programmes are costing more and more.

    Here I would like to raise a few questions: First, the SDF levy collection. I would like to know how many workers there are in the salary bracket of $750 to $1,000 per month. Are they concentrated in the small and medium enterprises? What is the amount of projected SDF collection per year for the next five years, with effect from the financial year 1995?

    Secondly, the SDF expenditure and sponsorship programme. In the dialogue sessions with the local small and medium enterprises, I gathered the impression that most of these SMEs felt that the training grants seem to favour the larger enterprises and have neglected the small and medium enterprises. I checked the annual report of the SDF for 1992/1993, and I found that for enterprises employing 10 workers and below, the grant is only 5% of the total grants of $60 million. For those enterprises employing 500 workers and below, they received a total of 59.2% of the grants. As at the end of March 1993, enterprises with 10 workers and below took up 82% of the 86,300 local enterprises. In other words, the smaller enterprises are not getting their proportionate share of the training grants.

    Moreover, the SME representatives also felt that the training plan tends to favour the managerial and supervisory staff, but not the skilled and semi-skilled workers. I hope that the Minister for Trade and Industry will clarify this matter. In addition, the SME also hopes that the SDF would give greater support to the skills development training courses conducted in Chinese.

    In the dialogue session conducted last month on this year's Budget, some participants felt that the Government should transfer the collection from the foreign workers' levy fully or partly into the Skills Development Fund so that the SDF would have more money to sponsor more and

Column: 980

better skills training courses. I know that the Minister for Finance has firmly adhered to his principle that all revenue should go to the Consolidated Fund, unless in very special circumstances.

    Last week, Mr Chew Heng Ching suggested setting up a special account for the collection of COEs so that it could be used to improve our roads. I think transferring the foreign workers' levy into the Skills Development Fund has the same implication of establishing a link between "taxation" and "benefit". This will have a few advantages because:

    Firstly, it would be easier for those who pay fees and taxes to shoulder the burden because they know that whatever tax that they have paid will go to good use;

    Secondly, the beneficiaries, eg, workers will see more clearly the benefits of certain policies; and

    Thirdly, the total revenue of the Government would not be reduced. This link between taxation and benefit will give the people a better understanding of our Government's policy and will help to foster a better relationship between the Government and the people.

    I hope that the Minister for Trade and Industry will urge the Minister for Finance to consider these suggestions from a broader perspective.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, education and training are continuous life-long processes. It has to be because the shelf life of knowledge is becoming shorter and shorter. Some people have suggested that the half-life of knowledge is now less than five years. In other words, within five years, half of what we have learnt will become obsolete.

    Sir, so far, Government's effort at training is commendable. The SDF has helped to train many workers who would otherwise have languished in ignorance and joblessness. So far, SDF training is largely employer-based. This means that employers will decide which courses are relevant and which courses are not so relevant. By and large, this policy is sound because many of our workers are still very much under-educated compared to our

Column: 981

NIE competitors. But in time, Sir, as the literacy rate of our workers improves, there will be less need for basic literacy, numeracy and even software courses. Instead, more courses will be required for updating the knowledge of skilled and professional workers. The problem in time will shift from one of training basic skills to one of providing continuing education. The objective of continuing education is of course to maintain the currency of skills and knowledge.

    Sir, my personal philosophy is that as our literacy rate improves, we will have to look at the concept of training anew. Slowly, over time, more individual-based training schemes should be devised to work in conjunction with the SDF which can continue to be employer-based. I would like to propose that a separate account be created in the CPF scheme for all working adults. This scheme, perhaps, could be known as the training fund. This training fund is in addition to the Ordinary, Special and Medisave accounts. But unlike these three accounts, ie, Ordinary, Special and Medisave accounts, which are actually components of employer and employee contributions, the training fund is a Government contribution. The fund serves as an incentive for training, but the money in the training fund is not a hand-out, so there is no welfare. The money can only be used for co-payment of approved training courses. At the same time, the working adult is encouraged to use this fund within, say, five years. If the fund is not utilised, the money in the training fund goes back to the Government. In other words, Sir, there is urgency as well as purpose in the matter. I would like the Government to consider this proposal.

     Dr Ow Chin Hock: Sir, under this amendment, I would like to bring up the issue of retail business.

    Despite the strong growth of our overall economy, the retail business sub-sector grew by only 4.9% last year. Within the retail sub-sector, the two main activities are (a) the distribution of motor vehicles and other transport equipment, and

Column: 982

(b) supermarkets, departmental stores, and general provision shops, each accounting for about 25% of the total retail turnover.

    The growth in the retail sub-sector last year was mainly contributed by motor vehicle sales. If we exclude motor vehicle sales, then the volume of retail business grew by only 1% last year, as compared to 5.2% in 1992. According to the Annual Economic Survey 1993, departmental stores encountered dismal sales, and a few departmental stores have in fact reported interim losses for the six-month period ending September 1991 and there were also closures of some retail outlets.

    At the same time, the number of tourist arrivals reached 6.4 million, an increase of 7.3% over the 1992 figure. Although the average stay went down from 3.7 days to 3.6 days, the total tourism expenditure was estimated to be around $9.36 billion, or 9.4% higher than the 1992 figure.

    Against this background, may I ask the Minister for Trade and Industry a few questions on the retail business and tourism?

    (a) How many percent of the total demand for retail business came from tourists? What was the average expenditure, other than expenditure on hotel, food and beverages, per tourist per day?

    (b) What is the present status of the retail development plan?

    (c) To what extent will the retail business be affected by GST? Is the machinery for refunding GST to tourists now in place?

    Finally, was there a trend for the retail business to shift from the CBD area to the suburban areas or HDB new town centres, even before the whole-day ALS was introduced?

     Mr Chia Shi Teck (Nominated Member): May I first declare that I believe in this Suzhou Township Project? However, as this is a huge project and the first of its kind to be undertaken by the Government, I would like to seek some clarification to enable the people of Singapore to know what we are in for, and how each and

Column: 983

everyone of us can participate directly or indirectly and benefit from the project. It is not new for the Singapore Government to invest overseas, but hitherto it has been in portfolio management or simply in capital gains investments, strategic investments like bringing back technology, transfer, or playing a catalytic role, as in our cluster development. All these investments so far have very little or no management requirement on the part of the Singapore Government.

    But this Suzhou Township Project is totally different. We are talking about a huge scale - 70 square kilometres, ie, more than 10% of Singapore's land size, 700,000 people to be staying there, 25% of Singapore's population, and 250,000 jobs. How much money is to be thrown in? It must be hundreds of millions of dollars. And what time frame are we talking about? 10, 20, 30, 50 years? We also read about the hardware, the infrastructure, that is led by Keppel Corporation, which is a GLC, but the Government is providing the software. That means opening up all the expertise that we have in the Singapore machinery. So what is the actual cost to us in terms of money and manpower? And the worry, as expressed by Mr Leong earlier, do we have that number of people? Where does the money come from? Are there other hidden costs? How does it benefit the people of Singapore and the country? And is it an extension of Singapore's territory, ie, if I cannot apply for a flat in Bishan or Pasir Ris, can I now apply for one in Suzhou? Is the NTUC going to build holiday chalets so that I can go there and relax and play golf? What kind of returns on investments are we talking about as against the other normal kind of investments? And can I get to work there any time? [Laughter.] Let us not laugh because these are questions that are being raised now and interests are stirred to a point that we may be able to just shift over there and live.

    Will there be many more of such townships should Suzhou be successful? What are the competitions that it will bring to Singapore in the longer term? Will that be a threat to Singapore's very survival? What about brain drain? The people that we have sent overseas are given special

Column: 984

privileges. What if the professionals or civil servants choose not to come home? We have done this with incentives by offering citizenship and permanent residence to foreign nationals working here. So the same could be done to our people working in Suzhou. Are there any political implications? Are we certain that the move will not backfire? As this project involves sticking out the neck of the country, it therefore cannot be viewed solely from the economic point of view.

    Whatever answers the Minister may give later, I hope the press will take it up as this is important. We have to inform the people of Singapore out there.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, I will take the questions as they were raised. The first four speakers touched on GST and they asked what Government is going to do to contain profiteering and inflation.

    Sir, the concerns are understandable. They are worried that GST would lead to profiteering, induce a price spiral, and lead to runaway inflation. I will address the concerns in three areas. Firstly, the inflationary threat of GST, what Government can do and will do to prevent profiteering and the forecast of inflation for this year.

    Sir, let me first assure the House that GST will not lead to high inflation. Singapore is not the first country to implement GST and therefore the lessons that we can gain from the experience of the other countries would be useful. I will be brief.

    Sir, the International Monetary Fund in 1986 carried out a study on 35 countries which had implemented GST. The finding was that of the 35, 29 countries experienced a one-off increase in inflation and subsequently the inflation rate dropped back to its normal level. What is also important to note is that the increase in inflation rate was in most cases lower than the actual GST rate that was imposed. For example, in Japan (Japan introduced a GST at a rate of 3%, it is the same as Singapore), the increase in the inflation rate, when it was implemented, was only 1.5%, only half that of the GST rate.

Column: 985



    Mr Koo, on Friday, I think, explained very well the underlying factors that would prevent the GST from having a high inflationary impact on Singapore, mainly low GST rate, our open economy, the offsets that are available, the high threshold for companies. I would like to thank him because he has saved me a lot of time explaining all that, and he is right.

    Sir, in terms of what are we going to do about profiteering, I think we have to bear in mind that ours is an open economy and therefore there is very little scope for profiteering. We have no shortage of goods and we have many suppliers all keenly competing for the consumer dollars. In fact, the competition today is keener than ever before.
